problem.tex: Prove that a Riemann surface $M$ is orientable.

solution.tex:
Recall that $M$ is orientable if we are able to choose local coordinates $\{U, 	ilde{\varphi} \}$, $\{V, \varphi \}$ such that $\det(J(	ilde{\varphi} \circ \varphi^{-1})) > 0$ for all transition functions $	ilde{\varphi} \circ \varphi^{-1}$. We can write the transition maps as $	ilde{\varphi} \circ \varphi^{-1} = \mu(x,y) + i 
u(x,y)$. The Jacobian is a $2$ by $2$ matrix so we have \[N := J(	ilde{\varphi} \circ \varphi^{-1}) = \left[ { egin{array}{cc}  rac{\partial\mu}{\partial x} &  rac{\partial \mu}{\partial y} \  rac{\partial
u}{\partial x} &  rac{\partial
u}{\partial y} \ \end{array} } ight]\] First, note that since $M$ is a Riemann surface, the transition functions are holomorphic and therefore satisfy the Cauchy Riemann equations. Second, note that transition maps are nonsingular so the determinant is nonzero. Then we get \[\det(N) =  rac{\partial\mu}{\partial x} rac{\partial
u}{\partial y} -  rac{\partial\mu}{\partial y} rac{\partial
u}{\partial x} = \left( rac{\partial \mu}{\partial x}ight)^2 + \left( rac{\partial\mu}{\partial y}ight)^2 > 0 \] Hence $M$ is orientable.
